subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
author: April Abercrombie
full_text:
------=_NextPart_000_004D_01C9D188.DC5BC910
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

OK...I did my test with a 4.43 MB wav file.

I experienced no noticeable lo=
ss, and the file was the same size before and after being emailed.

That st=
ill doesn't prove that maybe in some situations loss is possible.

But agai=
n, like RJ, I have never experienced it myself.

  ----- Original Message -=
---- 
  From: Rj 
  To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Sunday, May 10, 20=
09 3:35 PM
  Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON




=

        A file's content, it's integrity, is simply the bytes (and their b=
its) in the file.  If the file's content integrity is changed, that is, by =
definition, changing the bytes.  If the bytes in there are not changed, the=
n that integrity has not changed.

        It is possible to mess with othe=
r things about a file (like its name, its suffix, or its ownership) but thi=
s does not effect the contents, and so would not affect that integrity, or =
the sound of the file (assuming you could read it at all after changing the=
 ownership, or the suffix, etc).

        When you do your tests, if you ca=
nnot do a bit level comparison, I would recommend at least checking the fil=
e sizes.  If they are identical, there is a very high probability that the =
content has not changed.




        --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie=
 <april@...> wrote:


          From: April Abercr=
ombie <april@...>
          Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC]=
 File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON
          To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com
 =
         Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 2:28 PM



          Admittedly I do n=
ot know much about bit-level comparisons, what they can or can't show so I =
will have to leave that to you. I have doubts because I worry once a file's=
 integrity has been messed with, I wonder that even though the bits match, =
maybe that doesn't mean they are the same quality as the original. I really=
 don't know though what is possible or impossible when it comes to this are=
a.

          "It is probably possible to set up an email compression schem=
e that does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  =
If you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I s=
ee, lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual."

         =
 The problem I have is that not just from Jon, but I have heard it from oth=
er people, and a professional and they all said that loss is possible. From=
 all that, my conclusion was that maybe in some cases loss was possible.

 =
         However, your arguments do put doubt back into my mind, which piss=
es me off, because I had originally argued feverishly for no loss, then I h=
eard different from different sources and decided to do what I thought was =
the right thing by contacting a third party professional. So after all that=
, I decided I was licked and had to eat crow.

          Now I am back at s=
quare one, from the other side LOL!!! Computer people have been wrong in th=
e past.


          "It is probably possible to set up an email compression=
 scheme that does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does =
not.  If you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From wh=
at I see, lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual."

   =
       I have not tested it from my computer, as I haven't had any problems=
 with loss. I would really like to have Jon work with us on this, because h=
e was the original person who told me I was wrong.

          But I will te=
st it from my side. I will send a wav file to one of my other addresses. Th=
en I will download and compare. If I think I hear a difference, then maybe =
I can have you do a bit-level comparison on the files.

          Either wa=
y, I am going to get to the bottom of this.



            ----- Original M=
essage ----- 
            From: Rj 
            To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .co=
m 
            Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:59 PM
            Subject: Re: =
[EVP-ITC] File uploading rules-ATTENTION JON


                  Yes you ca=
n tell loss of quality by a bit-level comparison.  An audio file is just a =
file of bytes, that is later interpreted by an audio player.  Two files wit=
h the exact same contents, whether they are audio or image or a dababase or=
 an exe, are indistinguishable from each other.  That is, if I copied the c=
ontents of one to a new file, and the contents of the other to a new file, =
and asked you which file each came from, there would be no way to tell.  Ev=
en the audio player could not tell.  The data is identical, and so the soun=
d (or the picture, etc) would be identical.

                  Yes I did li=
sten to the results, but that is not the best test (they sounded identical,=
 but that is a subjective opinion).  The real test is compring the contents=
.  Identical contents means indentical data, means identical audio.

      =
            It is probably possible to set up an email compression scheme t=
hat does do lossy audio compression.  My tests show my setup does not.  If =
you'd like me to help test your setup, we can do that too. From what I see,=
 lossy compression from an attachment would be very unusual.


            =
      --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresear=
ch. com> wrote:


                    From: April Abercrombie <april@abercr=
ombiegh ostresearch. com>
                    Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File u=
ploading rules-ATTENTION JON
                    To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .c=
om
                    Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 1:50 PM



             =
       I have not personally experienced the loss myself. Jon from this lis=
t is the one who originally told me about it. I have also heard of it happe=
ning to a few other people. After my conversation with Jon, I talked to a c=
omputer professional, and he told me that you can experience loss in attach=
ed files.

                    I don't know if you would be able to tell lo=
ss of quality in an audio file with a bit-level comparison. Just because th=
e data has been replaced, doesn't have to mean it is perfect.

            =
        Did you listen to the before and after results?

                  =
  Jon-Please relay your experience with the loss of quality on emailed file=
s.


                      ----- Original Message ----- 
                  =
    From: Rj 
                      To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
         =
             Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 2:38 PM
                      Subje=
ct: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


                            I can'=
t vouch for your computer or servers, but I just did some tests, and sent a=
 2.1MB wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once allowing compression, and =
once turning it off.   I was able to verify that one was compressed and one=
 was not, by checking the sizes when they arrived at Yahoo. Once they came =
back to MSN, I then did a bit-level comparison of the original, and the one=
s sent around email.  They were all identical, which indicates lossless com=
pression.

                            If you have a file you'd like me to =
test for you, let me know.  But I wouldn't take someone's word for how your=
 server's work, without testing them yourself.



                         =
   --- On Sun, 5/10/09, April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch.=
 com> wrote:


                              From: April Abercrombie <april=
@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com>
                              Subject: Re:=
 [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                              To: EVP-ITC@y=
ahoogroups .com
                              Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 1=
2:50 PM



                              For executables, you may be right.=
 However, for wav files, the compression during email is not loss less. 

 =
                             I used to think as you do, in that the emailed=
 attachment of a wav file would not loose anything. After a lengthy discour=
se with another member here, I learned that I was wrong. The reason why I d=
id not realize it in the first place is that when I would email a wav file,=
 I would intentionally keep it in very small segments, to keep file size do=
wn. This was just for ease of transfer. But because of this, I had not expe=
rienced any noticeable loss.

                              Now it may be i=
n some cases, depending on the servers or what have you that the file goes =
through, that the loss may be less or more. But once the attachment is down=
loaded, the quality has been found to be less then the original wav.

     =
                         Again though you can only really tell when the wav=
 file is large.

                              ----- Original Message -----=
 
                                From: Rj 
                               =
 To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com 
                                Sent: Sunday=
, May 10, 2009 1:36 PM
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-IT=
C] File uploading rules


                                The kind of compr=
ession that occurs during an email attachment is "lossless": it compress th=
e file cleverly without losing information.  For example, if I had a progra=
m in some .exe files, and I sent it over email, it could compress it.  But =
if it lost even one bit, the resulting exe file would not execute again aft=
er it was uncompressed on the other side.

                                =
This kind of compression does things like looking for common patterns in th=
e file, and replacing them with a token.  A rough example would be if it fo=
und "Howdy Neighbor" in a file 20 times, it could replace all the occurance=
s with say $HN1.  And also write a little dictionary in there someplace tha=
t says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".

                                When the f=
ile gets to its destination it can be uncompressed, and all occurences of $=
HN1 are replaced with "Howdy Neighbor".  So it was compressed (instead of 1=
4 characters each, it only needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no data=
.

                                Some formats, like jpeg and mp3. are not=
 lossless.  Depending on the level of compression, some level of data is lo=
st, and so cannot be recovered or reconstructed later.

                   =
             Rick



                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, A=
pril Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresearch. com> wrote:


          =
                      From: April Abercrombie <april@abercrombiegh ostresea=
rch. com>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploa=
ding rules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
   =
                             Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 10:26 AM



      =
                          Another thing:

                                I=
 recently found this out. When you email a file, if it is not saved as a co=
mpressed format, the email filtering process will actually compress the fil=
e automatically.

                                So even if you have attac=
hed a wav. file, it will loose resolution over the email process. It will n=
ot sound exactly the same as the original wav. file. How much it differs de=
pends on the size of the file you are attaching. If it is a very large file=
, it will sound much different.

                                The only e=
xception to this is if the wav. file is small enough that the filtering pro=
cess will ignore it. It has to be pretty small though, like under 1 MB (I a=
m not exactly sure of the threshold).

                                The =
best way to share files over the internet if you want them as close to the =
original as possible is to upload them directly to a website.

            =
                    ----- Original Message ----- 
                         =
       From: Rj 
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .c=
om 
                                Sent: Sunday, May 10, 2009 10:54 AM
   =
                             Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules


=

                                Pixelization doesn't clean-up the data: it=
 replaces it.  Imagine taking a picture of a field of flowers, and beginnin=
g to add levels or pixelization to the picture.  Soon, you would not be abl=
e to tell there were flowers there at all.  You would see a lot of colored =
blocks.

                                Or in the other direction, imagine=
 you are looking at a competely randomize bunch of pixes on your screen: a =
complete screen of truely random static snow.  Pixelizing this, after a whi=
le, you would again start to see colored blocks.

                         =
       What's happening is that it is processing an area of the image, taki=
ng (for instance) the average value of that entire area, and replacing all =
the blocks in that area with the average.  In video processing, this would =
result in a field of multi-colored flowers being replaced by, for instance,=
 a big greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to flowers.  In the noise =
example, it maybe replace all the random pixels with another big greyish-bl=
uish block.  If you did not know beforehand what the original picture was, =
you couldn't tell whether your pixelized image was really a field of flower=
s, a chevy, the sky with clouds, or a random bunch of pixels.

            =
                    It works the same with the sound files.  Taking somethi=
ng as complex as speech, and replacing frequencies with their averages, los=
es the speech the farther you go, until you head strange fluctuating square=
 waves.  Doing the same to random static will eventually produce the same t=
hing.  And random fluctuating square waves can sound a bit like speech - or=
 at least, you could have fun sharing with each other what you thing they '=
sound like'.





                                --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Mist=
y Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrote:


                                Fr=
om: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com>
                                Sub=
ject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
                                To=
: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                                Date: Sunday, Ma=
y 10, 2009, 9:29 AM


                                I always save the who=
le file in wav format then do my clips as mp3. Then I have the original for=
 analysis. 

                                As far as pixelization of non =
sounds/white noise whos to say that isnt being manipulated by them as well =
LOL. Water is a form of white noise. I seem to remember some experiments do=
ne with blank tapes/film, no recording done yet there were voices/images th=
ere. I find it all interesting.

                                Just a tho=
ught. Ok off to work now!
                                Misty

          =
                      --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com> wrote:
=


                                From: Rj <rasterer@yahoo. com>
          =
                      Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading rules
         =
                       To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
                       =
         Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 11:47 AM


                           =
     Be a bit careful of formats like mp3 if you are doing a detailed analy=
sis of the sounds though.   While some formats (like wav) can store the aud=
io very close to the way it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress the fil=
e, and in so doing lose some of the sonic details.  This may not be a big d=
eal in music, where the audio is fairly clear to begin with.  But with soun=
d sources with a lot of noise (like evps), this can not only obscure any re=
al sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like white noise) and make them start t=
o sound like speech.

                                So mp3 might be good =
for sharing the data, once you've already formed an opinion based on an ana=
lysis of the wav file.  But mp3 is not good as a medium for analysis.  It c=
an lead to many false positives and misinterpretations.

                  =
              --- On Sun, 5/10/09, Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.com> wrot=
e:


                                From: Misty Dawn <bulletbabea@ yahoo.c=
om>
                                Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] File uploading r=
ules
                                To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
         =
                       Date: Sunday, May 10, 2009, 8:26 AM


              =
                  Thanks =3D)

                                 You will ge=
t the hang of it. Kristen is right thats how you save it. For most software=
s its under save as or export as. If you still have trouble use one of the =
links I posted to help ya out.

                                Misty

    =

ps.com accounts or elsewhere to be shared here using links. 

             =
                   Misty

              <TR>
                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Yes you ca=
n tell loss of quality by a bit-level 
                  comparison.  =
An audio file is just a file of bytes, that 
                  is later int=
erpreted by an audio player.  Two files with 
                  the ex=
act same contents, whether they are audio or image or a 
                  =
dababase or an exe, are indistinguishable from each 
                  othe=
r.  That is, if I copied the contents of one to a new 
               =
   file, and the contents of the other to a new file, and asked 
          =
        you which file each came from, there would be no way to 
          =
        tell.  Even the audio player could not tell.  The 
      =
            data is identical, and so the sound (or the picture, etc) 
    =
              would be identical.<BR><BR>Yes I did listen to the results, 
=
                  but that is not the best test (they sounded identical, bu=
t 
                  that is a subjective opinion).  The real test is =
compring 
                  the contents.  Identical contents means in=
dentical data, 
                  means identical audio.<BR><BR>It is proba=
bly possible to set 
                  up an email compression scheme that =
does do lossy audio 
                  compression.  My tests show my =
setup does not.  If 
                  you'd like me to help test your=
 setup, we can do that too. 
                  From what I see, lossy compr=
ession from an attachment would be 
                  very unusual.<BR><BR>=
<BR>--- On <B>Sun, 5/10/09, April

 <TD vAlign=3Dtop>I can't vouch for your computer or 
                     =
       servers, but I just did some tests, and sent a 2.1MB 
              =
              wav file from MSN to Yahoo and back, once allowing 
         =
                   compression, and once turning it off.   I 
   =
                         was able to verify that one was compressed and one=
 
                            was not, by checking the sizes when they arri=
ved at 
                            Yahoo. Once they came back to MSN, I th=
en did a 
                            bit-level comparison of the original,=
 and the ones 
                            sent around email.  They we=
re all identical, 
                            which indicates lossless com=
pression.<BR><BR>If you 
                            have a file you'd like=
 me to test for you, let me 
                            know.  But I =
wouldn't take someone's word for 
                            how your serv=
er's work, without testing them 
                            yourself.<BR><=

   <TABLE border=3D0 cellSpacing=3D0 cellPadding=3D0>

                   =
             <TD vAlign=3Dtop>The kind of compression that 
               =
                 occurs during an email attachment is "lossless": 
        =
                        it compress the file cleverly without losing 
     =
                           information.  For example, if I had a 
    =
                            program in some .exe files, and I sent it over =

                                email, it could compress it.  But if =
it 
                                lost even one bit, the resulting exe fi=
le would 
                                not execute again after it was un=
compressed on 
                                the other side.<BR><BR>This =
kind of compression 
                                does things like looki=
ng for common patterns in 
                                the file, and re=
placing them with a token.  
                                A rough e=
xample would be if it found "Howdy 
                                Neighbo=
r" in a file 20 times, it could replace 
                                al=
l the occurances with say $HN1.  And also 
                           =
     write a little dictionary in there someplace 
                        =
        that says "$HN1=3DHowdy Neighbor".<BR><BR>When the 
               =
                 file gets to its destination it can be 
                  =
              uncompressed, and all occurences of $HN1 are 
               =
                 replaced with "Howdy Neighbor".  So it was 
         =
                       compressed (instead of 14 characters each, it 
     =
                           only needed 4, plus the dictionary), but lost no=
 
                                data.<BR><BR>Some formats, like jpeg and =
mp3. 
                                are not lossless.  Depending on =
the level 
                                of compression, some level of da=
ta is lost, and 
                                so cannot be recovered or =
reconstructed 
                                later.<BR><BR>Rick<BR><BR><B=
R><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                                5/10/09, April Abercr=
ombie 
                                <I><april@abercrombiegh ostresear=
ch. 
                                com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
           =
                     <BLOCKQUOTE

              =
                  <DIV><FONT size=3D2 face=3D"Myriad Pro">I recently

l

 the

ro"></FONT> </DIV>

 face=3D"Myriad Pro">The only

that the filtering process will ignore

 It has to be pretty small though, like under

>
                                <TD vAlign=3Dtop><BR>Pixelization doesn't=
 clean-up 
                                the data: it replaces it.  =
Imagine taking a 
                                picture of a field of flo=
wers, and beginning to 
                                add levels or pixel=
ization to the picture.  
                                Soon, you wo=
uld not be able to tell there were 
                                flowers=
 there at all.  You would see a lot 
                                o=
f colored blocks.<BR><BR>Or in the other 
                                d=
irection, imagine you are looking at a 
                                com=
petely randomize bunch of pixes on your 
                                sc=
reen: a complete screen of truely random 
                                s=
tatic snow.  Pixelizing this, after a 
                               =
 while, you would again start to see colored 
                             =
   blocks.<BR><BR>What's happening is that it is 
                         =
       processing an area of the image, taking (for 
                      =
          instance) the average value of that entire area, 
               =
                 and replacing all the blocks in that area with 
          =
                      the average.  In video processing, this 
       =
                         would result in a field of multi-colored flowers 
=
                                being replaced by, for instance, a big 
   =
                             greyish-bluish block, with no resemblance to 
=
                                flowers.  In the noise example, it may=
be 
                                replace all the random pixels with anot=
her big 
                                greyish-bluish block.  If you=
 did not know 
                                beforehand what the original=
 picture was, you 
                                couldn't tell whether yo=
ur pixelized image was 
                                really a field of f=
lowers, a chevy, the sky with 
                                clouds, or a=
 random bunch of pixels.<BR><BR>It 
                                works t=
he same with the sound files.  
                                Taking=
 something as complex as speech, and 
                                repla=
cing frequencies with their averages, loses 
                              =
  the speech the farther you go, until you head 
                          =
      strange fluctuating square waves.  Doing 
                      =
          the same to random static will eventually 
                      =
          produce the same thing.  And random 
                       =
         fluctuating square waves can sound a bit like 
                   =
             speech - or at least, you could have fun sharing 
            =
                    with each other what you thing they 'sound 
           =
                     like'.<BR><BR><BR><BR><BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
        =
                        5/10/09, Misty Dawn <I><bulletbabea@ 
          =
                      yahoo.com></I></B> wrote:<BR>
                    =
            <BLOCKQUOTE

yle=3D"FONT-FAMILY: inherit; font-size-adjust: inherit"

              vAlign=3Dtop>
                                <DIV>I always s=
ave the whole file in wav format 
                                then do m=
y clips as mp3. Then I have the 
                                original f=
or analysis. </DIV>
                                <DIV> </DIV>
     =
                           <DIV>As far as pixelization of non sounds/white =

                                noise whos to say that isnt being manipula=
ted by 
                                them as well LOL. Water is a form o=
f white 
                                noise. I seem to remember some exp=
eriments done 
                                with blank tapes/film, no re=
cording done 
                                yet there were voices/im=
ages there. I find it 
                                all interesting.</DI=
V>

                                <TBODY>
                       =
         <TR>
                                <TD vAlign=3Dtop>Be a bit car=
eful of formats like 
                                mp3 if you are doing =
a detailed analysis of the 
                                sounds though.&=
nbsp;  While some formats 
                                (like wav) =
can store the audio very close to the 
                                way =
it was recorded, formats like mp3 compress 
                               =
 the file, and in so doing lose some of the sonic 
                        =
        details.  This may not be a big deal in 
                     =
           music, where the audio is fairly clear to begin 
               =
                 with.  But with sound sources with a lot of 
        =
                        noise (like evps), this can not only obscure any 
 =
                               real sounds, but pixelize non-sounds (like w=
hite 
                                noise) and make them start to sound l=
ike 
                                speech.<BR><BR>So mp3 might be good fo=
r sharing 
                                the data, once you've already fo=
rmed an opinion 
                                based on an analysis of th=
e wav file.  But 
                                mp3 is not good as a=
 medium for analysis.  
                                It can lead to=
 many false positives and 
                                misinterpretatio=
ns.<BR><BR>--- On <B>Sun, 
                                5/10/09, Misty D=
awn <I><bulletbabea@ 
                                yahoo.com></I><=
/B> wrote:<BR>
